awd_titl_txt: Integration of Computing in Rural Agricultural Education
awd_abstract_narration:
As computing has become integral to the practice of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM), the STEM+Computing program seeks to address emerging challenges in computational STEM areas through the applied integration of computational thinking and computing activities within STEM teaching and learning in early childhood education through high school (preK-12). This proposed Exploratory Integration study is to determine under what conditions integrating computation and computational thinking in agricultural education and problem solving will increase student interest, motivation, performance in courses, independent projects, and technical careers. It is expected that students will gain proficiency in the application of programming to solve specific problems in agriculture and will derive interest in pursuing computational science and/or computing in their future academic courses and career selection. The objectives of the project include creating an educational program for students composed of four introductory and two advanced modules focused on agriculture challenges. Investigators will utilize online training workshops to prepare the participating cohort of teachers to effectively implement the education program, and to build a peer-support network to support teacher success. This project is an integration of computation within agricultural science to provide an opportunity to build a youth career model that will be applicable or adaptable to the multitudes of rural agriculture communities and schools in the Nation. 

Many national reports indicate the need for advancing computer science and advancing the integration of computing into STEM content in response to computationally-intensive careers, but there is a scarcity of studies examining embedding computing into non-computing careers and technical courses, such as agriculture science or agricultural mechanics classes. Thus, this agricultural-based project will address an important gap in academic research and the impact of computational agriculture on the future workforce. Although primarily-rural industries like agriculture and natural resource management are becoming increasingly technical and computationally-driven, rural students see themselves as consumers of these technologies rather than potential creators of the technologies and applications. Rural students continue to be underserved in computing and STEM education. This project will address these deficiencies by deriving high-quality educational courses exposing students to computing in a way that will appeal to the culture of the rural audience. Investigators want to know: under what conditions does integrating computing skills and competencies to address and help solve agricultural problems, increase student interest, motivation, and career opportunities? Further, how do students of different demographic and academic backgrounds interact with the computing-modified agriculture curriculum? Do these students have similar engagement patterns, performance, interest, and attitude changes? How do teachers' implementation models lead to greater classroom impact? Finally, what aspects of the implementation and integration influence student engagement and interest in future computing and STEM courses and careers?
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The Agricultural Applications of Computer Science (Ag-ACS) project found that it is feasible for a variety of non-programming teachers of non-programming courses to implement physical programming and computational thinking into their traditional curricula, given adequate professional development and support resources.  Through the project, rural schools that rarely have any dedicated computer science courses have been able to provide microcomputer coding learning experiences to their students in a relevant and culturally responsive way by framing the activities within an agricultural context.

Ag-ACS researchers worked with technical college Industrial Engineering instructors and grade 6-12 pilot teachers to develop interchangeable challenge modules that introduce physical computing through agricultural challenges with Arduino and Raspberry Pi microcomputers, such as creating a moisture-sensitive irrigation system or a greenhouse temperature sensor that logs data online.  These tasks can fit individually into a variety of other STEM courses or be bundled to create a new engineering course, both of which were done successfully by pilot teachers.  The agriculture teachers in the pilot cohort demonstrated that roughly half of the performance objectives in Advanced Ag Mechanics courses could be achieved by utilizing Ag-ACS activities, and the remaining objectives could be supported by physical programming components built into traditional activities, such as automating the operation of a bigger welding project created by a student.  The skills and computational strategies learned by the students resulted in a wide variety of independent student projects, including a fishing-pole alarm, a laser door alarm, an automatic pet feeder, and others.

Teacher job changes throughout the project gave the researchers an opportunity to examine the effectiveness of Ag-ACS curriculum in both formal and informal learning environments.  A pilot educator at a nature center created several day camps and short programs for students from upper elementary through high school. She combined content from multiple modules to create a model of a wetlands flood control system with several inputs and outputs that students can program to open different gates to allow water to flow where needed.  She has also modified the smartphone app module to combine computer technology and biology field experiences, teaching students to create an app that they immediately use to count the different types of animals they find in a hands-on stream study.  She has used other modules to create livestreams and timelapse videos of animals at the center. 

A pair of pilot teachers developed a summer zoo camp in which middle school students learned about caring for zoo animals, then programmed prototype tools like automatic animal feeders to make the care easier and more reliable.  

 

Students were successfully engaged by the Ag-ACS activities, according to teacher feedback and interviews, along with student surveys.  They were not shown to be significantly steered from previous career interests toward computer science careers by working with the Ag-ACS curriculum, but survey results showed an increased appreciation for how computer programming and computational thinking skills can support the other STEM paths of interest.  Nearly all student participants with a strong interest in a specific non-computer STEM career field reported enjoying the Ag-ACS activities.  These students will go into other careers with computer science skills, computational thinking strategies, and positive computer attitudes, making them more capable of capitalizing on the benefits of computers and automation in any field.  An introductory section of the curriculum specifically addresses how computer technology is used in agriculture and other rural industries, with the intent of showing students that there are high-tech career opportunities in rural areas that might be suited to someone from a rural background with the right technical skills. 

In addition to the numerous educators reached through conference presentations for the National Science Teaching Association, National Association of Career & Technical Educators, Association for Educational Communications & Technology, Kansas Science Teaching Association, and the 2019 STEM For All Video Showcase, the final year of the project achieved a targeted dissemination strategy focused on reaching preservice teachers and expanding workshops to other regions of the country.  Through five hands-on workshops at three Kansas universities and a 7-county STEM hub in Oregon, 59 educators and soon-to-be educators learned how to access and utilize the Ag-ACS curriculum resources and to program electronic inputs and outputs to create their own physical programming solutions to simple daily challenges.  Giving inexperienced teachers an opportunity to experiment with and experience success with Ag-ACS activities should greatly improve their comfort levels and likelihood of introducing these activities to their future students, when this opportunity would not exist otherwise, particularly in small rural schools.

The curriculum was exclusively available to pilot teachers throughout most of the project in order to improve and refine the content and user interface.  As dissemination expanded in the final year,  the materials were built into a new website for public access.  The full Ag-ACS curriculum can be found at http://bit.ly/ag-acs.

por.por_txt_cntn:
The Agricultural Applications of Computer Science (Ag-ACS) project found that it is feasible for a variety of non-programming teachers of non-programming courses to implement physical programming and computational thinking into their traditional curricula, given adequate professional development and support resources.  Through the project, rural schools that rarely have any dedicated computer science courses have been able to provide microcomputer coding learning experiences to their students in a relevant and culturally responsive way by framing the activities within an agricultural context.
Ag-ACS researchers worked with technical college Industrial Engineering instructors and grade 6-12 pilot teachers to develop interchangeable challenge modules that introduce physical computing through agricultural challenges with Arduino and Raspberry Pi microcomputers, such as creating a moisture-sensitive irrigation system or a greenhouse temperature sensor that logs data online.  These tasks can fit individually into a variety of other STEM courses or be bundled to create a new engineering course, both of which were done successfully by pilot teachers.  The agriculture teachers in the pilot cohort demonstrated that roughly half of the performance objectives in Advanced Ag Mechanics courses could be achieved by utilizing Ag-ACS activities, and the remaining objectives could be supported by physical programming components built into traditional activities, such as automating the operation of a bigger welding project created by a student.  The skills and computational strategies learned by the students resulted in a wide variety of independent student projects, including a fishing-pole alarm, a laser door alarm, an automatic pet feeder, and others.
Teacher job changes throughout the project gave the researchers an opportunity to examine the effectiveness of Ag-ACS curriculum in both formal and informal learning environments.  A pilot educator at a nature center created several day camps and short programs for students from upper elementary through high school. She combined content from multiple modules to create a model of a wetlands flood control system with several inputs and outputs that students can program to open different gates to allow water to flow where needed.  She has also modified the smartphone app module to combine computer technology and biology field experiences, teaching students to create an app that they immediately use to count the different types of animals they find in a hands-on stream study.  She has used other modules to create livestreams and timelapse videos of animals at the center. 
A pair of pilot teachers developed a summer zoo camp in which middle school students learned about caring for zoo animals, then programmed prototype tools like automatic animal feeders to make the care easier and more reliable.  

 
Students were successfully engaged by the Ag-ACS activities, according to teacher feedback and interviews, along with student surveys.  They were not shown to be significantly steered from previous career interests toward computer science careers by working with the Ag-ACS curriculum, but survey results showed an increased appreciation for how computer programming and computational thinking skills can support the other STEM paths of interest.  Nearly all student participants with a strong interest in a specific non-computer STEM career field reported enjoying the Ag-ACS activities.  These students will go into other careers with computer science skills, computational thinking strategies, and positive computer attitudes, making them more capable of capitalizing on the benefits of computers and automation in any field.  An introductory section of the curriculum specifically addresses how computer technology is used in agriculture and other rural industries, with the intent of showing students that there are high-tech career opportunities in rural areas that might be suited to someone from a rural background with the right technical skills.

Through five hands-on workshops at three Kansas universities and a 7-county STEM hub in Oregon, 59 educators and soon-to-be educators learned how to access and utilize the Ag-ACS curriculum resources and to program electronic inputs and outputs to create their own physical programming solutions to simple daily challenges.  Giving inexperienced teachers an opportunity to experiment with and experience success with Ag-ACS activities should greatly improve their comfort levels and likelihood of introducing these activities to their future students, when this opportunity would not exist otherwise, particularly in small rural schools.

The curriculum was exclusively available to pilot teachers throughout most of the project in order to improve and refine the content and user interface.  As dissemination expanded in the final year,  the materials were built into a new website for public access.  The full Ag-ACS curriculum can be found at http://bit.ly/ag-acs.
